oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Songwriter Session - Bruce Robison - 2017-09-16
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Performance by singer songwriter Bruce Robison from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on September 16, 2017. Includes questions from the audience. In partnership with the Americana Music Association. Accompanied by Geoff Queen on dobro and harmony vocal.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Bruce Robison; Geoff Queen;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Walk-on music / (02:54) Opening announcements by Abi Tapia / (04:10) Walk-in Music continues / (06:10) Opening comments by Abi Tapia and introduction of Chuck Taylor / (08:30) Taylor introduces Bruce Robison / (10:20) Opening comments from Bruce Robison / (10:47) Introduces the first song / (11:38) Performs Sweet Dreams / (15:28) Talks about the previous song / (16:55) Introduces the next song and performs Desperately / (21:18) Talks about the thrill of having George Strait record the previous song / (22:40) Introduces the next song / (24:03) Performs Leavin' / (27:37) Answers question about how his songs first became noticed / (31:40) Answers question about the complication and simplicity of songwriting / (32:30) Introduces the next song / (33:50) Performs Angry All The Time / (37:57) Comments on the previous song, the inspiration behind writing it and how it found it's way to Faith Hill / (40:16) Introduces the next song / (41:31) Performs Travelin' Soldier /

(45:45) Comments on the previous song / (47:17) Answers question about co-writing songs in Nashville versus Texas / (48:37) Answers question about his background influencing his songwriting / (49:50) Answers question about harmony singing / (50:50) Answers question about the base for his his songwriting and says it's based in the blues / (52:01) Answers question about considering himself a country artist / (52:56) Closing comments / (53:21) Walk-out music / (58:05) FILE END
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Robison, Bruce; Queen, Geoff; Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum (Nashville, Tenn.);
